page_analysis.text_content:
Gross vs. net lot area

Gross lot area is the size of the lot—from lot line to lot line.
Development potential is based on the net lot area and
while gross and net lot area are the same for most lots in
Palo Alto, there are some lots for which portions must be
excluded from the gross lot area to establish the net lot area.

Areas excluded from the gross lot size are:

• Street right-of-way (Area A of Fig 1 on this page)
• “Pole” portion of a flag lot (Area B of Fig 2 on this page)
• Creek channel (Area C of Fig 3 on this page)

Fig 1 Gross lot area exclusions: street easements

Lot with
boundaries
that extend
into the
public ROW

The portion of the lot within the
public ROW must be subtracted
from the gross lot area.

Note: In some areas of Palo Alto, like
Barron Park, it is not unusual for the
lot to extend to the middle of the
street. However
purposes, the lot is defined by the
edge of the public street easement or
public right-of-way (ROW).
Dimensions for the public ROW are
available at the Development Center

Fig 2 Gross lot area exclusions: flag-lot “poles”

Flag lot
accessed via
private
easement

Flag lot with
“pole”

Street

“pole” portion of a
lot must be subtracted
the gross lot size

: Private access easements
ots that provide access to
lots are NOT subtracted
the lot on which they occur.

Fig 3 Gross lot area exclusions: creek easements

Creek
easement

Top of
bank

The portion of the lot within a
creek channel must be subtracted
from gross lot size.

Note: The channel or area to be
subtracted is defined by Santa Clara
Valley Water District’s easement or, if
there is no easement, the top-of-bank.
Determining the top-of-bank may
require a surveyor.

visual_elements.description: Figure 1: Gross lot area exclusions: street easements. Shows a street with two cars (Area A) and a 'Public ROW' (Right-of-Way). A lot boundary extends into the public ROW, indicating that the portion of the lot within the public ROW must be subtracted from the gross lot area. Includes a note about lot definition in Palo Alto and where to find ROW dimensions.

Figure 2: Gross lot area exclusions: flag-lot 'poles'. Depicts two flag lots, one accessed via private easement and another 'Flag lot with pole'. Area B, the 'pole' portion of the flag lot, is shaded, indicating it must be subtracted from the gross lot size. A note clarifies that private access easements are NOT subtracted.

Figure 3: Gross lot area exclusions: creek easements. Illustrates a lot adjacent to a creek with a 'Creek easement' (Area C). The shaded area within the creek channel is marked for subtraction from the gross lot size. A note explains that the channel/area to be subtracted is defined by Santa Clara Valley Water District's easement or the top-of-bank, and may require a surveyor.
Legend for the diagrams, defining symbols for Curb, Sidewalk, Lot lines, Creek, and Area that must be subtracted from gross lot area.

subheadings: Areas excluded from the gross lot size are:
sections: Fig 1 Gross lot area exclusions: street easements
Fig 2 Gross lot area exclusions: flag-lot “poles”
Fig 3 Gross lot area exclusions: creek easements

additional_notes: The text 'However purposes' in the note for Fig 1 appears to be a partial sentence or missing words, possibly due to a scanning error or original document formatting.
The character 'A' in Fig 1 is within the street, indicating the 'Street right-of-way' area.
The character 'B' in Fig 2 is within the 'pole' portion of the flag lot, indicating the area to be subtracted.
The character 'C' in Fig 3 is within the creek channel, indicating the area to be subtracted.
The page number '3' is present at the bottom right.
